Issues.Title: angular.dev URL fragment links broken on api pages.
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

I was looking at the [Angular animations documentation for transitions](https://angular.dev/api/animations/transition?tab=api) on angular.dev and I noticed a link about State Change Expressions. Clicking the link redirected me to the root of the site instead of to a section of Useage Notes.

It appears this link works correctly on the [old site](https://angular.io/api/animations/transition).

After some research I have determined that the old site had all information about the function in a flat structure on the page where as "angular.dev" has a tabular view separating the API from the Usage Notes which causes the URL fragment links to break.

Issues.Title: fix(core): allow attribute injection with inject function
Issues.Body:
Before the `inject` function users were able to inject attributes using the `@Attribute` decorator. While we don't have an equivalent with `inject`, it is possible to use `inject(new Attribute('foo') as any)` to get the same result.

These changes expand the type of `Attribute` so users don't have to cast to `any`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(core): allow attribute injection with inject function" (#53672)

Issues.Body: The `ComponentFixture` code needlessly dances around the `ngZone` being `null` when the `ComponentFixtureNoNgZone` option is set. Instead, it can use the `NoopNgZone` to get the same effect without needing to have checks all over the place for its presence.

Issues.Title: zone.js 0.13.1+ - Jest `spyOn` no longer works for functions imported with `import * as`
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

zone.js

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

We're working in an Nx monorepo and attempting to migrate to Nx 17 (17.1.2, to be exact) with Angular 17. This version of Nx brings zone.js 0.14.2.

With these new versions, unit tests that `spyOn` functions imported with `import * as` fail with error `TypeError: Cannot redefine property`.

When downgrading to zone.js 0.13.0 this error does not occur. The error begins to occur with zone.js 0.13.1.
___
One workaround that we discovered is to add a `jest.mock(...)` for the library that is being imported from. Using the example from the minimal reproduction repository:
```ts
...
import * as x from 'my-lib-a';

// TODO: This is required for `spyOn` to work using zone.js 0.13.1+
jest.mock('my-lib-a');

describe('AppComponent', () => {
  ...
  ...
  ...
  it(`should have as title 'my-app-a'`, () => {
    jest.spyOn(x, 'getNumber').mockReturnValue(2);
    const fixture = TestBed.createComponent(AppComponent);
    const app = fixture.componentInstance;
    expect(app.title).toEqual(2);
  });
```
However, we're unsure if this is a reliable workaround.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/abaran30/nx-angular-playground/tree/zone.js-0.13.1-spyOn

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
FAIL   my-app-a  apps/my-app-a/src/app/app.component.spec.ts
  AppComponent
    ‚úì should create the app (71 ms)
    ‚úï should have as title 'my-app-a' (1 ms)
    ‚úì should render title (11 ms)

  ‚óè AppComponent ‚Ä∫ should have as title 'my-app-a'

    TypeError: Cannot redefine property: getNumber
        at Function.defineProperty (<anonymous>)

      21 |
      22 |   it(`should have as title 'my-app-a'`, () => {
    > 23 |     jest.spyOn(x, 'getNumber').mockReturnValue(2);
```

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 17.0.1
Node: 18.15.0
Package Manager: npm 9.5.0
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: 17.0.3
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1700.1
@angular-devkit/build-angular   17.0.1
@angular-devkit/core            17.0.1
@angular-devkit/schematics      17.0.1
@angular/cli                    17.0.1
@schematics/angular             17.0.1
ng-packagr                      17.0.2
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.2.2
zone.js                         0.14.2
```


### Anything else?

### Steps to reproduce

1. Clone repository https://github.com/abaran30/nx-angular-playground
2. Checkout branch `git checkout zone.js-0.13.1-spyOn`
3. Run `npm ci`
4. Run `npx nx run my-app-a:test`

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler): Fix ambiguous repeater context variables in template pipeline
Issues.Body:
In #52931, Kristiyan fixed a TemplateDefinitionBuilder bug in which derived alias variables in for loops (`$even`, `$first`, etc) were referring to the wrong level of nested `@for` block. (These variables are unique because they become inlined expressions, and are not "real" context variables.) He fixed this by appending level information to the generated alias name.

Template Pipeline actually suffered from the same bug. We fix it in a very similar way -- in particular, whenever these derived context variables are used, we make them depend on versions of `$index` and `$count` that have been suffixed with the xref of the enclosing repeater.

I have added a few more pipeline goldens, because we are not quite as clever as TDB about only generating the duplicate suffixed index and count variables when inside nested loops. This is fine, since in the long run, we want to refactor it more fundamentally.

Accordingly, I have added a TODO to fix this more rigorously. In particular, it would be nice if we had proper support for shadowed variables, as well as unlimited levels of variables depending on one another.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(compiler): Fix ambiguous repeater context variables in template pipeline" (#53662)

Issues.Title: Integrate Advanced Performance Monitoring Tools for Angular Applications
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

Angular's current development toolkit offers robust features for building dynamic web applications. However, as applications grow in complexity, developers often face challenges in optimizing performance, particularly in areas like rendering, change detection, and data binding. Presently, there's a lack of intuitive, Angular-specific tools for monitoring and visualizing these performance aspects, making it difficult to pinpoint inefficiencies and bottlenecks.

### Proposed solution

I propose the development of an integrated performance monitoring suite within Angular's ecosystem. This suite would offer real-time insights and visualizations about the application's performance directly within the development environment. Key features of this suite could include:

- Component Rendering Analysis: Visual tools to track and display rendering times for each component, helping identify components that cause significant delays.
- Change Detection Profiling: Monitoring tools to observe and report the frequency and duration of change detection cycles, highlighting inefficient patterns or unnecessary triggers.
- Optimization Recommendations: Automated suggestions for performance improvements, such as implementing lazy loading, optimizing data binding strategies, or leveraging Angular's OnPush change detection.
- Customizable Dashboard: A configurable interface allowing developers to focus on metrics most relevant to their specific application.

### Alternatives considered

- Third-Party Performance Tools: While external tools offer some insights, they often lack the deep integration and understanding of Angular's inner workings necessary for detailed analysis and specific optimization recommendations.
- Manual Performance Debugging: Developers can manually profile applications using existing browser tools. However, this process is often time-consuming and requires in-depth knowledge of Angular's framework internals.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Integrate Advanced Performance Monitoring Tools for Angular Applications" (#53661)

Issues.Title: fix(platform-server): Do not delete global Event
Issues.Body:
This commit removes a hack that deletes `Event` from the global context when using domino. Instead, it sets the global event to domino's implementation of `Event`.


The "Trick to avoid Event patching" links to a state in the repository that is 6(!) years old: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/7cf5e95ac9f0f2648beebf0d5bd9056b79946970/packages/platform-browser/src/dom/events/dom_events.ts#L112-L132. A lot has changed since then. I don't know what the implications might be with this change but @tbondwilkinson and I are encountering issues with events when working with the navigation API that are caused by this bit of hackery.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(platform-server): Do not delete global Event" (#53659)

Issues.Title: Add info for required inputs in ComponentMirror inputs array
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

If we create ComponentMirror from some component, there is an array with all the inputs from that component, but currently, there is no way to determine if that input is required or not.
`reflectComponentType(component).inputs` - This will give only an array of inputs with no info for `required: true`

### Proposed solution

`reflectComponentType(component).inputs` - This array should be an array of objects where we will have the name of the input and info about whether is it required or not, something like:
`[{name: "inputName", required: true}]`

### Alternatives considered

There is no other way to determine if the input is required because it's info in the decorator.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add info for required inputs in ComponentMirror inputs array" (#53653)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): filter explicit external dependencies for Vite prebundling
Issues.Body:
To ensure that Vite does not unintentionally attempt to prebundle a module that was explicitly marked as external (typically via the `externalDependencies` build option), the full list of externalized imports is now filtered by the dependencies specified within the external configuration. Vite currently will include a module for prebundling if it is present in the include list even though it may also be present in the exclude list.

Closes #26730
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): filter explicit external dependencies for Vite prebundling" (#26735)

Issues.Title: externalDependencies and lodash causes error
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

17.0.0

### Description

When using the application builder's ``externalDependencies`` property to make ``lodash`` external, ng serve responds with the following error the first time, lodash is used:

```
X [ERROR] The entry point "lodash" cannot be marked as external
```

This behavior does not occur with ``@angular/core``, ``@angular/common``, or any other dependency directly installed by the CLI.

### Minimal Reproduction

Reproduction:

1. Create a new Angular app (``ng new``)
2. ``npm i lodash``
3. ``npm i @types/lodash -D``
4. Add this option to the application builder in the ``angular.json``:             
    ```
    "externalDependencies": ["lodash"],
    ```
5. Use ``lodash``, e. g. in your ``AppComponent`` (see https://github.com/manfredsteyer/external-reproduction/blob/main/src/app/app.component.ts)
6. ``ng serve -o``
7. Once ``lodash`` was used for the first time, the above-mentioned error message is shown on the console

Please find a minimal example reproducing the issue here:
https://github.com/manfredsteyer/external-reproduction.git

### Exception or Error

```text
X [ERROR] The entry point "lodash" cannot be marked as external
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 17.0.7
Node: 20.10.0
Package Manager: npm 10.2.3
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 17.0.8
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1700.7
@angular-devkit/build-angular   17.0.7
@angular-devkit/core            17.0.7
@angular-devkit/schematics      17.0.7
@angular/cli                    17.0.7
@schematics/angular             17.0.7
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.2.2
zone.js                         0.14.2
```


### Anything else relevant?

_No response_

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

- `ng new` command logs `‚úî Packages installed successfully.` even though `--skip-install` was specified and no packages were installed.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): `ng e2e` and `ng lint` prompt requires to hit Enter twice to proceed on Windows
Issues.Body:
This fixes an issue where prompts in nested child processes on Windows require multiple keystrokes to proceed.

Closes #26724

    *Thank you [@​willstott101](https://togithub.com/willstott101)*

    *See [here](https://togithub.com/lukeed/mrmime/commit/30fb9013019ea8de176b4fc7ba2b4919765bd7db#diff-245325387efd8aa8aac268ce36d381f28be82af225b8aa72dad83ff23fd522eb) for visual diff*

    **Removed:**

    -   `es`

    **Changed**

    -   `asc` :: `application/pgp-signature` => `application/pgp-keys`
    -   `js` :: `application/javascript` => `text/javascript`
    -   `mjs` :: `application/javascript` => `text/javascript`
    -   `rtf` :: `application/rtf` => `text/rtf`
    -   `xml` :: `application/xml` => `text/xml`

    **Added**

-   Alphasort `mimes` keys on build: [`f071512`](https://togithub.com/lukeed/mrmime/commit/f071512)
-   Simplify `pnpm` in CI: [`50c135b`](https://togithub.com/lukeed/mrmime/commit/50c135b)

Issues.Title: test: always use package manager force option in version add command E2E
Issues.Body: The goal of the `commands/add/version-specifier` test is to check the behavior of the `ng add` command itself and not that of the package manager. To do so requires adding a package using a variety of different version specifiers. Some of which a package manager may consider incompatible with the hosting project. However, this is not relevant to the selection logic of the `ng add` command which should select the version as designed. To verify it does so within the Angular CLI, the installed version needs to be checked. As a result the package manager must install the package.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "test: always use package manager force option in version add command E2E" (#26720)

Issues.Title: [Angular 17] Wrong sass variable resolution with fontawesome on first `ng test` run
Issues.Body:
### Command

test

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

16.x

### Description

The first time I run `ng test` I get several errors related to invalid paths where `$fa-font-path` seems to be resolved incorrectly as `../node_modules/@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/scss/@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/webfonts/fa-brands-400.ttf` whereas the actual path is `../node_modules/@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/webfonts/fa-brands-400.ttf`.

The error does not occur when running `ng test` a second time. The app itself runs fine with `ng serve` with styles and icons being displayed correctly. 

I'm not sure whether this is an error with Angular or somewhere in the chain of Karma, sass, post-css, fontawesome etc.

### Minimal Reproduction

1. Create a new project `ng new` with scss
2. Add karma configs `ng generate config karma`
3. Install FontAwesome `npm i @fortawesome/fontawesome-free`
4. Import fontawesome scss files in `styles.scss`
```scss
$fa-font-path: '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/webfonts';
@import '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/scss/fontawesome.scss';
@import '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/scss/brands.scss';
```
5. Run tests with `ng test`

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): ensure external dependencies are used by Web Worker bundling
Issues.Body: When processing a Web Worker reference in application code, the Web Worker entry point is bundled in a separate action. The external dependencies configuration was previously not passed on to this action which caused the Web Worker bundling to attempt to bundle any configured external dependencies. Issues.Title: Tailwind @screen Directive does not work with Application builder but previously worked with Webpack builder
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, serve

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

_I create a new issue based on my previous one https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/26644#issuecomment-1857633589 since it's a different topic now._

I've reproduced the issue successfully with the old, but still valid directive `@screen` (even if not documented). If this isn't supposed to work the ESBuild, then I wonder what the upgrade path (from `@screen` to `@media screen (xy)`) would be. It seems like nothing is mentioned anywhere?

See https://github.com/mirobo/nx-angular-tailwind/tree/main and (maybe you need to run `npm install` it with legacy peer deps). Then `npm run start` (it starts both variants).

Resize the window to see colors of the h1 with "TAILWIND SCREENS TEST" change (the variant with ESBuild won't work)

I see that both executors do something with postcss and autoprefixer internally (which are both added as dependencies in this test project), but only the Webpack executor seems to have a "sass-loader" [webpack/configs/styles.ts](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/tools/webpack/configs/styles.ts#L226C36-L226C47) while in [esbuild..sass-language.ts](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/tools/esbuild/stylesheets/sass-language.ts) and [esbuild..stylesheet-plugin-factory.ts](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/tools/esbuild/stylesheets/stylesheet-plugin-factory.ts) I didn't find it.

The styles.css produced by both bundlers is pretty much identical: https://github.com/mirobo/nx-angular-tailwind/tree/main/style-css-output

![image](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/assets/78788210/fe0b872f-14fe-4c07-bac0-f5fa33c4e46b)

In the generated main.js I see that some processing was not done:

**ESBuild**

![image](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/assets/78788210/a0d81c4b-be0c-40ad-b40c-f9adeeac59e4)

**Webpack**

![image](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/assets/78788210/b1f7ae27-c35e-4617-97b3-a31d3b5a1aa3)

### Minimal Reproduction

- clone https://github.com/mirobo/nx-angular-tailwind/tree/main
- `npm install`  (maybe run it with legacy peer deps). 
- `npm run start` (it starts both variants, one with Application builder and one with Webpack).
- Resize the window to see how the header `TAILWIND SCREENS TEST` changes color (in case of Webpack) and how it doesn't change color (in case of Application/ESBuild builder)

Issues.Title: refactor(material/expansion): remove incorrect `inputs` overrides
Issues.Body: The bases classes of the CDK already define the input with transforms. Technically the new `inputs` declarations override the full metadata, loosing the transforms. This is currently a bug in the framework where components relied on the behavior that transforms were inherited independently. This commit fixes this and cleans up the code. The inputs do not need to be re-declared.

Issues.Title: feat(google-maps): add support for dynamic library loading API
Issues.Body:
Currently the `@angular/google-maps` module is implemented on top of the legacy `<script>` API which is problematic, because:
1. It loads all of the JavaScript up-front, even if there are no maps on the page.
2. It requires the user to ensure that the API is fully loaded before the `<google-map>` component starts rendering. Lazy-loading in this scenario is error-prone and loading the API up-front leads to a lot of unused JavaScript being loaded.

These changes add support for the [Dynamic Library Import API](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/javascript/load-maps-js-api#dynamic-library-import) which requires a tiny script to be added up-front which then allows the `<google-map>` to load the chunks of the API it needs on-demand. The legacy API is still supported, but is no longer recommended.

All the components also now have `initialized` outputs to make it easier to know when the underlying Maps classes have been created and can be interacted with.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(google-maps): add support for dynamic library loading API" (#28307)

Issues.Title: feat(dialog): set default actions alignment with injection token
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

I want the dialog actions to be aligned to the right by default. Currently this is not part of the [`MatDialogConfig`](https://material.angular.io/components/dialog/api#MatDialogConfig), so it cannot be set via the `MAT_DIALOG_DEFAULT_OPTIONS` injection token. It can only be achieved by setting the `align` input for each usage of the [`mat-dialog-actions`](https://material.angular.io/components/dialog/api#MatDialogActions) component:

```html
<mat-dialog-actions align="end">
</mat-dialog-actions>
```

My suggestion is to add an optional `alignActions` property to the `MatDialogConfig` interface to control the default alignment.

### Use Case

The actions alignment should be changeable at a single point, so it is easier to maintain in larger code bases.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(dialog): set default actions alignment with injection token" (#28302)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-select): 'disableOptionCentering' input option not working
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14.2.7

### Description

In Angular Material v14, by default, the selected active option would be centered when you open up the dropdown. It was the 'disableOptionCentering' input option that would determine whether to center the active option over the trigger. 

After upgrading to Angular Material v16, this option has no effect, though the API documentation for v15+ still lists it as an available Input. Since there is an effort with v15+ to better align with Material Design Components (MDC), it seems that 'disableOptionCentering' functionality is not supported. If so, please update the API documentation and code to remove support of this input option.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/fe9vgg?file=src%2Fapp%2Fselect-overview-example.html
Steps to reproduce:
1. Open dropdown and select an option
2. Re-open dropdown and notice that the selected active option is not centered
3. Add 'disableOptionCentering' input and set to false on mat-select


### Expected Behavior

The selected active option would be centered when you re-open the dropdown.

### Actual Behavior

The selected active option is not centered when you re-open the dropdown. The dropdown options open directly below the mat-select component.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.2.12
- CDK/Material: 16.2.10
- Browser(s): Google Chrome (Version 120.0.6099.109)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(mat-select): 'disableOptionCentering' input option not working" (#28293)

Issues.Title: Enhanced Support for Dynamically Setting Attributes Across Angular Material Components (e.g. `mat-fab`, to Change Button Variants at Runtime).
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

This feature would enable developers to update not only the appearance of Material Design buttons but also other components dynamically, based on user interactions or other real-time factors. The ability to dynamically update attributes such as mat-fab, and others that significantly alter the layout or styling, is currently limited post-initialization.

The existing workarounds for this limitation are often complex and can significantly impact performance.

**Current Workarounds and Their Limitations**: 

I have attempted several approaches, including:

1. **Manually setting the attribute using Renderer2 and ElementRef**: While this method provides direct control over component attributes, it can lead to verbose and complex code, especially when dealing with multiple attributes and components. Moreover, it requires careful management of Angular's Lifecycle, adding a layer of complexity in ensuring that attribute changes align with Angular's change detection and update cycles.
    
2. **Creating a Proxy around the component element to intercept and apply attribute changes**: This approach offers a degree of flexibility and a more elegant solution for attribute manipulation. However, it adds an additional layer of complexity and can be challenging to manage across different components. Additionally, the reliance on Metaprogramming techniques, which are less familiar to many developers, can hinder maintainability and reduce the ease of updates.
    
3. **Forcing the component to re-render by updating a key value within an `*ngIf` directive**: This approach, although effective in certain scenarios, can lead to performance issues. It involves destroying and recreating components, which is inefficient and resource-intensive, especially for large and interactive UIs. Such a method goes against Angular's philosophy of efficient, reactive UI updates and can drastically affect the user experience in more complex applications.

### Use Case

In many web applications, the UI needs to respond dynamically to user actions and other application states. For example, a button may need to change from a standard button (`mat-button`) to a floating action button (`mat-fab`) based on a user's selection or a specific state in the application. 

Currently, such dynamic changes require workarounds that are less efficient and potentially less performant. Having native support for this functionality would streamline the development process, reduce the need for custom solutions, and align Angular Material more closely with dynamic and reactive design patterns.

Another significant use case for this feature is the **creation of interfaces designed to configure other software interfaces.** 

Such UIs need to dynamically respond to runtime changes efficiently, adapting their appearance and functionality on the fly. 

This feature would be particularly valuable in scenarios where developers are building highly interactive and configurable environments, eliminating the need to prepare static lists of elements. Instead, developers could leverage Angular Material to dynamically adapt UI components like buttons to varying requirements and states, enhancing the overall flexibility and user experience.

This capability is crucial in modern software development, where adaptability and responsiveness are key to meeting diverse and evolving user needs and expectations.

We appreciate the continuous efforts of the Angular Material team in advancing the framework and thank you for considering this feature request.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Enhanced Support for Dynamically Setting Attributes Across Angular Material Components (e.g. `mat-fab`, to Change Button Variants at Runtime)." (#28292)

Issues.Title: bug(MatButton): FAB with disabled state using alpha on background collisions
Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description Because the disabled state background color is defined with alpha, FAB collide with page contents when disabled. There's no guideline anywhere stating that FAB should never get disabled, and a disabled FAB is even part of the documentation. FAB stands for Floating Action Button according to https://m3.material.io/components/floating-action-button/overview so it should be assumed most uses will be with absolute or fixed positioning. ### Reproduction StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/4rnhsm?file=src%2Findex.html,src%2Fexample%2Fbutton-overview-example.html,src%2Fexample%2Fbutton-overview-example.css Steps to reproduce: 1. Have a FAB button 2. Make it disabled ### Expected Behavior The button doesn't get visually mixed with the page contents. One potential solution would be to make the disabled state not use alpha. ### Actual Behavior Page contents as partially visible background on the button decrease its readability. ### Environment - Angular: 17.0 - CDK/Material: 17.0 - Browser(s): any - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): any
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatButton): FAB with disabled state using alpha on background collisions" (#28291)

Issues.Title: bug(matTabs): mat-tab-link leaves behind detached DOM elements when removed in Angular 16
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

In Angular 16 when "mat-tab-link" gets removed from the DOM it leaves behind detached DOM elements, which are not cleaned up by the garbage collector, resulting a memory leak.

**I can't reproduce this issue with Angular Material version 17.0.3. Would it be possible to include the fix in Angular Material version 16?**

![matTabsDomCount](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/153174614/d6b37458-ad04-432a-a16b-08e8b09762fd)



### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-d5ewez
Please download the code from stackblitz and run it locally.
Steps to reproduce:
1. Click "Toggle test" button multiple times while observing DOM node count in Chrome performance monitor (run GC manually)


### Expected Behavior

When you remove a ‚Äúmat-tab-nav-bar‚Äù that contains at least one ‚Äúmat-tab-link‚Äù and run the garbage collector, the DOM node count returns to its original value before the nav bar was created.

### Actual Behavior

When "mat-tab-link" gets removed from the DOM it leaves behind detached DOM elements, which are not cleaned up by the garbage collector.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.2.12
- CDK/Material: 16.2.12
- Browser(s): Google Chrome 120.0.6099.71 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Microsoft Windows Version 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3693)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(matTabs): mat-tab-link leaves behind detached DOM elements when removed in Angular 16" (#28289)
